results.title: Bitter Herbs and Honey
results.creator_credit: Monique Schwarz, Amber Films and Film Finance Corporation Australia
results.brief_description: Australian documentary focuses on the lives of European Jews who settled in the Melbourne suburb of Carlton in the 1940s, fleeing World War II atrocities and post-War conditions. Interestingly the Jews from Eastern Europe clashed with Anglo-Jews, settled in the nineteenth century, who identified as British rather than Jewish and disapproved of the too obvious presence of Sephardic Jews, with whom they feared association. Despite these and other difficulties, social groups thrived in the suburb, where people shared life, food, religion and a common experience. Local residents from the period, many recalling their childhood, discuss a marvellously rich and joyous, if impoverished, family life; others talk about the racism suffered at school and in the street; several recount the pain of being a Holocaust survivor and the trials of assimilation. Includes archival footage from the era interspersed with recreations and a slew of interviews that include: Pinchus Ringelblum, Hilary Rubinstein, Bernard Rechter, Solomon Pose, Victor Smorgon, Arnord Zable, Jean Holkner, June Factor, Freydi Mrocki, Sam Lipski, Amirah Inglis, Rachel Levita and Miriam Kuna. Features some marvellous Yiddish songs and several interviewees discuss their parents yearning to sustain the use of Yiddish language. With occasional English subtitles.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Monique Schwarz, Amber Films and Film Finance Corporation Australia

results.title: [Beam Software: interview with Alfred Milgrom]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

Alfred Milgrom, with business partner and marketing expert Naomi Besen, launched Beam Software in 1980. From the company’s beginnings as UK publishing firm, Melbourne House, Milgrom and Besen moved to Australia and opened up their software programming arm with Beam. He reflects on his years in the software industry and the innovations Beam initiated, both in games design and corporate culture.

results.title: [Beam Software: interview 3]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

Andrew Bailey and Trevor Nuridin discuss how they both entered the games industry and their work at Beam’s publishing arm, Melbourne House. They talk candidly about the culture at Beam and the reasons why they left to start Tantalus Media together in 1994.

results.title: Boys and Balls
results.creator_credit: Sue Thomson, Anna Grieve, Film Finance Corporation Australia, Gil Scrine Films and Thermal Falls
results.brief_description: It is in games many men discover their paradise. Robert Lynd. H.G. Nelson (Greig Pickhaver) and Rampaging Roy Slaven (John Doyle) host an amusing, often hilarious exploration of the fascination of men with balls; whether it is a cricket, football, tennis, basketball, soccer, bowls, table tennis, hockey or golf ball! Celebrities including Ted Whitten, Ron Barassi, Merv Hughes, Derek Kickett, Andrew Gaze, Lindsay Gaze, Francis Awaritife, Brad Mackay, Greg Champion and the average bloke and kid next door share favourite childhood memories of their sporting idols, humerous moments, coaching temperaments, the importance of rules and umpiring, and the incidence of sporting violence. Interviews, archival footage and famous quotes are intermixed in this perceptive program.

results.title: [Beam Software: interview with Greg Barnett]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

After graudating in computer science from Melbourne University, Greg Bennett joined Beam Software in 1982. Inspired by his dual interests in programming and film, Bennett designed and programmed the groundbreaking one-on-one martial arts game ‘The Way of the exploding fist’. He talks about the game industry over the years and the changes, both financial and creative, in relation to his career.

results.title: [Beam Software: interview with Bill McIntosh]
results.brief_description:
Beam Software produced a series of groundbreaking games in the 1980s, most notably the seminal games of ‘The Hobbit’, which allowed characters to direct other characters, and ‘The Way of the exploding fist’, one of the first one-on-one fighting games developed for the home computer. Beam was sold to Krome Studios in 2006 which, in turn, ceased operations in 2010. These unedited interviews with some of the key members of Beam Software were filmed at ACMI in April 2006.

Beam Software programmer, Bill McIntosh, left a boring job in the Royal Air Force to join Beam after his wife bought him a computer, which he equates with “plugging in his brain”. He discusses the games he worked on and the culture at Beam, and the financial conditions in Australia that put such companies at risk.

results.title: Alpine Playground
results.creator_credit: Cinesound and Tourist Development Authority of Victoria
results.brief_description: A holiday with a difference; the joys of an alpine winter holiday in Victoria’s picturesque skiing resorts, Mt Buffalo, Mt Hotham and Falls Creek. Within easy reach of Melbourne, facilities include expert ski instruction, readily available ski tows, toboggans, and comfortable accommodation.

results.title: Gippsland Honeymoon
results.brief_description:
A honeymoon couple tour the Gippsland area and admire the scenic attractions of the country-side. Depicts many of Victoria’s famous tourist attractions including: Lakes Entrance, Gippsland, Orbost, the Snowy River, the Tambo River, Bairnsdale, Omeo, Walhalla Goldfields, Buchan Caves, Mallacoota Inlet, La Trobe Valley, Glen Maggie Weir and Ninety Mile Beach. Produced in conjunction with The Tourist Development Authority and The Gippsland Lakes and Tourist Promotion Council.

This film was discussed on ABC Gippsland Radio on 14 March 2020. The following are comments for viewers which add insight into the film

Martin Richardson “Joe” is Joe Southon, from Paynesville who wasn’t actually a Lakes Entrance fisherman, but was the chosen “talent” for the movie - it was through his connections that the film crew came down here to make the movie. He was a farmer, part-time fisherman, and farm manager whose property occupied a large part of what is now the town of Paynesville. He was also involved in many civic roles around the Bairnsdale Shire. His daughter Beryl and son Bluey still live in Paynesville.

Ashley Meek My father features on this add fishing at the Glenmaggie spillway

Neil Walters who picked up one of the narrators was Ross Higgins. “put the money on the fridge wog.!” (Kingswood Country)

Graeme Nixon Cape Conran my dad jim nixon boat and me. Front boat
